tool_input.content:
--- theme: ../ layout: default clicks: 5 ---

What Skills Do I Need?

Everyone has different workflows

🔧
Backend Dev
API design, DB migrations, testing patterns
🎨
Frontend Dev
Component patterns, debugging, styling
📊
Data Engineer
Pipeline workflows, SQL patterns, ETL
🚀
DevOps
CI/CD, infra-as-code, monitoring
Cool examples everywhere... but what about you?

The Real Question

It's easy to get overwhelmed:
✗ "I need 50 skills to be productive"
✗ "Other people have amazing setups"
✗ "I don't know where to start"
The answer is simpler:
What do YOU do repeatedly?
Start there. Just one thing.

Find Your Repeated Workflows

Ask yourself:
  • "What do I do every PR?"
  • "What's my debugging process?"
  • "How do I onboard to new code?"
  • "What do I explain repeatedly?"
Look for patterns:
  • Same steps, different inputs
  • Things you could automate
  • Knowledge only you have
  • Processes you've refined
Start with ONE
Pick the workflow you do most often. That's your first skill.
You'll naturally find more as you work.

Real "First Skills" from Real Engineers

"My PR review checklist"
The 10 things I always check before approving
"How I debug React renders"
My systematic approach to finding render issues
"Our commit message format"
The team standard we always follow
"API endpoint scaffolding"
The boilerplate I write for every new endpoint
None of these are complex. They're just documented workflows .
The best skill to start with is the one you'll actually use tomorrow.

tool_input.content:
--- theme: ../ layout: default clicks: 5 ---

The Path Forward

You Can Have A Lot

# My actual .claude/ directory
.claude/
├── agents/ (7 files)
├── commands/ (28 files)
├── agent-session/ (4)
├── development/ (3)
├── git/ (2)
└── ...
├── hooks/ (3 files)
├── skills/ (98 files)
├── agent-session/ (21)
├── docs-framework/ (52)
└── ...
Total: 141 files
This is real:
  • Skills for planning workflows
  • Skills for documentation
  • Skills for code review
  • Skills for debugging
  • Custom commands
  • Agent configurations

This Can Seem Daunting

141 files
That's a lot of configuration.
⚠ "Where do I even start?"
⚠ "I don't have time for this"
⚠ "This seems overwhelming"
But here's the thing:
I didn't build this in a day.
This is months of iteration. Each skill started as ONE thing I needed.

The Process

1
Figure out what you need
"I keep doing this same thing..."
2
Make a skill
Start simple. Just the basics.
3
Iterate with you in the loop
Use it. Refine it. Repeat.
4
Pass it out
Share with team when it works.
This is the cycle. Every skill I have went through this.

Iterate With You In The Loop

❌ The Wrong Way
"Here's my workflow, agent.
Figure it out and do it."
Result: Bad skills that don't match how you actually work.
✓ The Right Way
→ Work alongside the agent first
→ Correct it when it's wrong
→ Refine the skill based on real use
→ Then step out of the loop
Start with one skill. Get it right. Then build from there.

tool_input.content:
--- theme: ../ layout: default clicks: 4 ---

Example: Front-End Debugging Skill

The Problem

Typical debugging session:
  • Component not rendering correctly
  • State updates not reflecting
  • Console full of warnings
  • Network requests failing silently
Every time: same investigation steps, same tools, same checklist...
What if the agent knew:
  • Your debugging methodology
  • Which tools to check first
  • Common issues in YOUR codebase
  • How to interpret YOUR error patterns

The Skill

# .claude/skills/frontend-debug/SKILL.md
---
name: frontend-debug
description: Systematic debugging for
React components, state issues, and render problems.
---
# Front-End Debugging
## When to use
User reports UI bug, render issue, or state problem.
## Debug Checklist
1. Check browser console for errors
2. Verify component props in React DevTools
3. Check network tab for failed requests
4. Review state management flow
...
This captures:
  • When to apply it
  • Steps to follow
  • Tools to use
  • Patterns to check

Supporting Files

frontend-debug/
├── SKILL.md
├── references/
├── common-errors.md
├── react-patterns.md
└── state-debugging.md
└── scripts/
└── check-renders.js
References contain:
  • Common errors + fixes
  • Your codebase patterns
  • Team conventions
  • Helper scripts

In Action

User
"The user profile isn't updating when I change the name"
Agent (with skill)
Follows your debugging checklist systematically
> Read .claude/skills/frontend-debug/SKILL.md
> Read .claude/skills/frontend-debug/references/state-debugging.md
> Following debug checklist...
> Checking UserProfile.tsx for state management...
The agent debugs the way you would.

tool_input.content:
--- theme: ../ layout: default clicks: 4 ---

What Skills Do I Need?

Everyone has different workflows

🔧
Backend Dev
API design, DB migrations, testing patterns
🎨
Frontend Dev
Component patterns, debugging, styling
📊
Data Engineer
Pipeline workflows, SQL patterns, ETL
🚀
DevOps
CI/CD, infra-as-code, monitoring
Different roles, different problems, different skills.

I have a lot of skills...

# My actual .claude/ directory
.claude/
├── agents/ (7 files)
├── commands/ (28 files)
├── agent-session/ (4)
├── development/ (3)
└── ...
├── hooks/ (3 files)
├── skills/ (98 files)
├── agent-session/ (21)
├── docs-framework/ (52)
└── ...
Total: 141 files
But what do I show you?
My workflow is probably not the same as yours.
What's useful for me or my team might not be what you need.
Everyone is different.

The Process (works for everyone)

1
Figure out what you need
What do you do repeatedly? What takes too long? What knowledge only you have?
2
Make a skill, iterate in the loop
Start simple. Use it. Refine it. Work alongside the agent until you're happy.
3
Pass it out or automate
Share with your team. Or step out of the loop entirely.
The skills you need are the ones that solve YOUR problems.
